content:
A FEW YEARS ago Jeff Bezos made a prediction. By 2018 his e-commerce empire, Amazon, would be delivering items by lass="word-wrap-span">drone. Prime Air has yet to launch. But startups are making progress—mostly in health care, where they are vying to tap into a lucrative, $70bn global market in health-care logistics. As they deal with regulators and investors, these firms are charting the course for other lass="word-wrap-span">aerial deliveries.

One of the best known is Zipline, based in San Francisco, which took off in lass="word-wrap-span">Rwanda in 2016, where it is now a national on-demand medical lass="word-wrap-span">drone network, delivering 150 medical products, mostly blood and vaccines, to hard-to-reach places. lass="word-wrap-span">Maternal mortality rates are declining thanks to the lass="word-wrap-span">delivery of blood. Other firms have used lass="word-wrap-span">drones to deliver medicines in Bhutan, lass="word-wrap-span">Malawi and Papua New Guinea. Patients in many lass="word-wrap-span">Swiss hospitals can receive results on the day a sample is taken. Zipline is expanding into lass="word-wrap-span">Ghana and, later this year, into North Carolina, an American state with many out-of-the-way rural medical facilities. It wants to serve 700m people in the next three to four years.

For governments and regulators nervous about allowing lass="word-wrap-span">Drones to roam the skies, health-care deliveries offer a compelling reason to give it a go. lass="word-wrap-span">Drones can fall out of the sky, can lass="word-wrap-span">collide with other air traffic, create perceived privacy concerns and they can be noisy. This is hard to justify when they are delivering a light lass="word-wrap-span">bulb. When they carry life-saving medicines the lass="word-wrap-span">calculation is different. It is also easier, says Ben Marcus, founder of AirMap, a lass="word-wrap-span">Drone-technology firm, because health-care deliveries typically happen between a limited number of fixed locations, not to and from lass="word-wrap-span">innumerable doorsteps.

Like most fast-growing startups, lass="word-wrap-span">Drone firms are lass="word-wrap-span">coy about profitability but say they are generating revenue. Investors look lass="word-wrap-span">convinced. On May 17th Zipline announced $190m in new financing, which values it at $1.2 billion. It and its competitors see lucrative opportunities. For one thing, medical parcels are lass="word-wrap-span">Lightweight but valuable, so lass="word-wrap-span">Drone costs would make up a relatively small portion of the final bill. lass="word-wrap-span">Drones can also replace stocks of expensive medicines hospitals keep just in case they are needed, by flying them quickly to the hospital bed from a central location. lass="word-wrap-span">Lightweight electric lass="word-wrap-span">Drones are likely to be less expensive than traditional car or motorcycle lass="word-wrap-span">courier, and faster. lass="word-wrap-span">Andreas Raptopoulos, boss of Matternet, another lass="word-wrap-span">Drone-lass="word-wrap-span">delivery firm, thinks that this could save hospitals millions in lab and pharmacy costs.

The prospect of such lass="word-wrap-span">efficiency gains (as well as eco-lass="word-wrap-span">friendliness) was factor in the partnership between lass="word-wrap-span">Swiss Post and Matternet. lass="word-wrap-span">Drones now service three cities in Switzerland. lass="word-wrap-span">Swiss Post says journeys of 45 minutes have been reduced to flights of a few minutes. Matternet is, like Zipline, moving into North Carolina, whose local transport authority has championed lass="word-wrap-span">Drone lass="word-wrap-span">delivery. UPS, a big lass="word-wrap-span">delivery company, is using Matternet’s lass="word-wrap-span">Drones to replace some lass="word-wrap-span">courier cars to move medical samples across the state. UPS lags behind lass="word-wrap-span">Swiss Post in lass="word-wrap-span">Drone lass="word-wrap-span">delivery but hopes that experience in health care will lay the lass="word-wrap-span">groundwork for national expansion.

The future of lass="word-wrap-span">drone deliveries of all kinds in America, and elsewhere, rests with regulators. In less-developed countries the skies are empty and permission to fly can be granted by a single person. In developed countries, with their more crowded lass="word-wrap-span">airspace and thicker rule books, everything takes longer.

The current lass="word-wrap-span">buzz in America is down to a pilot programme by the Federal lass="word-wrap-span">Aviation Administration (FAA), which hopes this will help it develop a regulatory framework. As part of the project, Zipline is expected next week to announce its plans direct-to-consumer health-care lass="word-wrap-span">delivery. Some expect that by the time the FAA pilot ends in November 2020, Mr Bezos will finally have his way.

CORRECTION JUNE 11th 2019 : A previous article called AirMap a lass="word-wrap-span">drone consultacy. This has been corrected.
